abstract.text: 40 41 SUMMARY 42 The outbreaks of 2019 novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) caused by 43 SARS-CoV-2 infection has posed a severe threat to global public health. It is unclear 44 how the human immune system responds to this infection. Here, we used 45 metatranscriptomic sequencing to profile immune signatures in the bronchoalveolar 46 lavage fluid of eight COVID-19 cases. The expression of proinflammatory genes, 47 especially chemokines, was markedly elevated in COVID-19 cases compared to 48 community-acquired pneumonia patients and healthy controls, suggesting that 49 SARS-CoV-2 infection causes hypercytokinemia. Compared to SARS-CoV, which is 50 thought to induce inadequate interferon (IFN) responses, SARS-CoV-2 robustly 51 triggered expression of numerous IFN-inducible genes (ISGs). These ISGs exhibit 52 immunopathogenic potential, with overrepresentation of genes involved in 53 inflammation. The transcriptome data was also used to estimate immune cell 54 populations, revealing increases in activated dendritic cells and neutrophils.

55 3 Collectively, these host responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection could further our 56 understanding of disease pathogenesis and point towards antiviral strategies. 57 75 Type-I IFN (IFN-I) response plays a critical role in combating virus infection mainly 76 by inducing the expression of interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) that exert antiviral 77 functions (Samuel, 2001). Meanwhile, viruses have developed strategies to counteract 78 IFNs. For example, SARS-CoV can efficiently suppress IFN induction and antagonize 79 IFN's effect by harnessing its structural and non-structural proteins (de Wit et al., 80 2016). SARS-CoV infection failed to induce competent IFN response in cultured cells 81 (Cheung et al., 2005; Spiegel and Weber, 2006; Ziegler et al., 2005) and SARS 82 patients (Reghunathan et al., 2005). The inadequate IFN response may account for the 83 4 progressive increase of viral load in SARS patients, the concomitant 84 hypercytokinemia, and the ultimate fatal outcomes. 85 Clinical study on COVID-19 suggested the hypercytokinemia in severe cases (Huang 86 et al., 2020). However, a more comprehensive investigation of the host immune 87 response is needed. Here, we collected the bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF) of 88 eight COVID-19 patients, 146 community-acquired pneumonia patients, and 20 89 healthy controls, followed by metatranscriptome sequencing and functional analysis.

90 The molecular signatures of the host response, especially the innate immune response 91 to SARS-CoV-2 infection, were explicitly depicted, showing distinct patterns from 92 those seen in SARS and pneumonia caused by other pathogens. 93 94 RESULTS 95 Sample collection, metatranscriptome sequencing, differential expression gene 96 analysis, 97 BALFs were obtained from laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 patients (SARS2) (n = 98 8), community-acquired pneumonia patients (CAP) (n = 146), and healthy controls 99 without known respiratory diseases (Healthy) (n = 20). The demographic and clinical 100 characteristics of the cohorts were detailed in Table S1 . By metatranscriptome 101 sequencing, more than 20 million reads were generated for each BALF sample from 102 SARS2, CAP, and Healthy. Among them, 56% of the reads could be mapped to the 103 human genome and were used for further analysis. As metatranscriptome data enabled 104 us to capture the transcriptionally active microbes, we further classified CAP into two 105 categories: Virus-like CAP (determined by at least 100 viral reads and 10-fold higher 106 than those in the negative controls) and Non-viral CAP. The read counts for 107 SARS-CoV-2 in each COVID-19 case were listed in Table S2 . 130 131 Global functional analyses 132 We then performed global functional analyses. For pathway analysis, we applied the 133 Ingenuity Pathway Analysis (IPA) and KEGG analyses on DEGs. In IPA, "Interferon 134

Signaling" ranked first in the upregulated pathways in SARS2 (z-score = 3.3, Figure   135 1C). This pathway is also upregulated, though to a lesser extent, in Virus-like CAP 136 (z-score = 1), whereas not in the Non-viral CAP ( Figure 1C ), indicating robust IFN 137 157 mainly composed of ribosomal proteins and chemokines, respectively (Figures 1D). 158 Overall, our global functional analysis revealed a highly responsive state against 159 noxious stimuli in COVID-19 cases, characterized by the potent defense responses 160 and hyperactive ribosome biogenesis.

FIGREF0.text: -19 outbreak caused by SARS-CoV-2 infection (Lu et al., 2020; Ren et al., 59 2020; Zhou et al., 2020; Zhu et al., 2020) has been declared as a global pandemic. 60 Typical clinical symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, cough, myalgia, and shortness of 61 breath (Huang et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2020). Severe cases often developed acute 62 lung injury, or the fatal form, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) (Chen et al., 63 2020; Huang et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2020). To date, no specific antiviral treatment 64 is available for COVID-19. 65 The infection of certain respiratory viruses often resulted in a robust inflammatory 66 response (de Jong et al., 2006; Huang et al., 2005). This immune dysregulation, 67 termed as hypercytokinemia or "cytokine storm", is often associated with detrimental 68 outcomes, such as ARDS (de Jong et al., 2006). To date, it remains elusive how 69 pathogen infections disrupt the host immune homeostasis and stimulate a hyperactive 70 proinflammatory response. A proposed model suggested that viral evasion of the 71 innate immune response plays a critical role (D'Elia et al., 2013): the virus can 72 effectively blind the immune system, causing an inadequate or delayed response; this 73 immune escape gives rise to the unrestrained virus replication, which eventually 74 results in a hyperactivated proinflammatory response.

Using the transcriptome data, we estimated 238 immune cell types and their proportions by CIBERSORT (Newman et al., 2015). 239 Similar to findings in BALF from healthy adults (Meyer et al., 2012), the BALF cell 240 components in Healthy were mainly macrophages and lymphocytes (Figure 4A). This 241 result supported the accuracy of the BALF cell sequencing and the effectiveness of 242 our analytical approach. Among innate immune cells, activated dendritic cells, 243 activated mast cells, and neutrophils were more abundant in viral pneumonia groups 244 than those in Healthy (Figure 4B). FIGREF12.text: such as avian influenza or SARS, occur in the lower respiratory tract (Gu 257 and Korteweg, 2007; van Riel et al., 2006), where the immune response was triggered 258 and regulated. Thus, blood transcriptome may not be optimal for profiling the 259 immunopathological features in those scenarios. In the current study, we sampled 260 COVID-19 patients with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL), a method for retrieving cells 261 and solutes from different areas of the lung (Meyer et al., 2012). By sequencing and 262 analyzing the BAL fluid cells from eight COVID-19 patients and control cohorts, we 263 obtained gene expression profiles of both host and virus, which directly reflected the 264 in situ host response against SARS-CoV-2 infection. We thus provided a valuable 265 opportunity to garner insights into COVID-19 pathogenesis.

FIGREF13.text: -19 patients, we observed the upregulation of a plethora of 268 proinflammatory cytokines, suggesting the pathogenic role of hypercytokinemia. The 269 most salient feature of the cytokine profile is the chemokine response, as seen from 270 the elevated expression of multiple chemokines and their receptors. Among those, 271 various neutrophil chemoattractants were upregulated. Consonant with this, the higher 272 neutrophil amount was observed in SARS2 by cell composition analysis. Also, 273 chemoattractants for monocytes and other immune cells were significantly 274 upregulated. In patients with ARDS, the alveolar spaces are occupied by the 275 infiltrating neutrophils and monocytes (Matute-Bello et al., 2008), suggesting the 276 pathogenic role of those cells. Thus, our data unraveled a possible 277 chemokine-dominant hyperactive cytokine response in COVID-19 cases.

FIGREF14.text: to SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2 triggered a robust IFN response, hallmarked 280 by the expression of numerous ISGs, including IFITMs shown to counteract protective potential of ISGs may account for the lower proportion of severe cases and 283 the case-fatality rate in COVID-19 as compared to SARS (Wu and McGoogan, 2020). 284 Nevertheless, high SARS-CoV-2 loads were detected very early after symptom onset 285 (Zou et al., 2020), suggesting that the virus may have developed countermeasures 286 against the IFN system, such as delaying the IFN response by inhibiting innate 287 immune signaling. Moreover, although robust ISG induction was observed, we failed 288 to detect significant upregulation of IFNs. This discrepancy needs further 289 investigation. 290 IFN-I could also be pathogenic. In the mouse model, depletion of IFN-α/β receptor 291 protects mice from lethal infection of SARS-CoV (Channappanavar et al., 2016). 292 Moreover, delayed IFN-β treatment failed to inhibit virus replication and aggravated 293 pulmonary inflammation in the mice infected with MERS-CoV (Channappanavar et 294 al., 2019). These data suggested that the timing of IFN therapy against SARS and 295MERS is critical. In the ISGs identified in COVID-19 cases, we found a subset of 296 genes with proinflammatory activities, which is relatively underrepresented in other 297 viral infections. These "proinflammatory ISGs" may assist the antiviral protection by 298 amplifying inflammatory signals to the environment. However, they could also be 299 deleterious in infections, especially when hypercytokinemia has already been 300 triggered. As IFN treatment has been adopted as an antiviral therapy against 301 SARS-CoV-2 infection (ChiCTR2000029600), the timing and dose should be 302 carefully considered.

Twenty-two immune cell subtypes were obtained and further 448 summarized into nine major immune cell types.
